newsitem.title: INDIA: Calcutta shares rise on short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Calcutta shares rise on short-covering.

text.p: Share prices staged a smart recovery to close higher on the Calcutta Stock Exchange on Wednesday on hectic short-covering, brokers said.
They said speculative sellers rushed to cover their positions anticipating prices to move up for technical reasons despite the absence of foreign institutional investors (FIIs) in the market,

Brokers said scrips like Reliance Industries and State Bank of India were expected to attract a stiff backwardation charge of about five rupees per share at close of current accounting period of the exchange on Thursday.
This prevented speculative sellers from forcing fresh sales, the brokers added.
"I do not think that prices can move up very much as most blue-chips will face strong upside resistance," said a dealer with brokers Jet Age Securities.
He said most blue-chips lacked the momentum to break resistance in the absence of buying interest from foreign funds.
Brokers said most scrips opened much higher than their previous close and moved in a narrow range. Only blue-chips were able to maintain their initial gains, the brokers said.
It was not so much as fresh buying but the retreat of speculative sellers that promoted the market to stabilise at higher levels, they added.
